However, mutations in F13L gene can cause viral resistance to ST-246 as demonstrated previously ( Yang et al., 2005; Lederman et al., 2012; Duraffour et al., 2015). To investigate whether the potent anti-VACV compounds identified in this study could inhibit ST-246–resistant virus, we infected cells with two different ST-246-resistant viruses in the presence of 10 μM PA104, PA24, and PA63. The two viruses used contained distinct resistance-conferring mutations; the first, hereby referred to as RV1, was isolated from the lesions of a PV patient by serial plaque purification in the presence of ST-246 ( Lederman et al., 2012). We sequenced the F13L gene of our isolated RV1 and found the previously reported resistance mutation A290V ( Figure 5A). The second virus, hereby referred to as RV2, was acquired from SIGA Technologies and contains the N267D resistance mutation ( Smith et al., 2011).
